reviewText:
I own and have beaten both the Collector's Edition and remixed versions.
---
Have you ever sat cross-legged with your left hand on your cheek, searching for that hidden gem RPG among the crowd? Congratulations, you may have just found that. If you're a fan of Bioware's old RPGs and older games such as Summoner, Severance, Enclave, Deathtrap Dungeon, Die by the Sword and the Elder Scrolls games there is a high chance you're going to really enjoy this one. Dungeon Lords is an old, but obscure, aged yet playable third person CRPG. The game supports unlocked framerate and fps in-game (unfortunately the menus are 23fps locked), which already puts half of modern PC ports to shame. For a 2005 remastered port, this is impressive. Now, what differs this game from other RPGs even ones considered masterpieces is what the game offers and how it presents itself.

Those games I listed? Combine them together, imagine they poly morphed as one game and grew up with just one parent. That's this game in a nutshell. The game offers real time combat with hotkeys, status screens, doll-like inventory, real-time changing portraits, and much more, which would take me beyond the word limit to list. Dungeon Lords also offers a point and click mode, which brings the cursor on-screen so you can play it like a traditional MMO, or you can just stick with the default action control system. The bog standard difficulty mode is there but in addition to a random encounter chance slider. No, that doesn't mean your world transitions into a battle mode" ala Final Fantasy
date: it just means the chance of random mob spawns. There's options for view distance

reviewText:
This is gonna sound all kinds of strange, but I'm recommending the game. Is the game good? Not at all! Is it fun? Yes. Yes it is.

Brief history lesson: Heuristic Park released version 1.0 of Dungeon Lords in 2005. It received patches in the classic sense - update files that you download, execute, point toward your install folder and let it to the work. These patches, however, didn't do much as far as I'm aware.

My history with it was that I got the Collector's Edition, a special rerelease which fixed several bugs and had a new character class and a tonne of new content! I found it when I was rather young at a dollar store. I didn't know why an RPG of such scale was in a dollar store, but lo and behold! I get back home, pop it into my Windows XP computer and give it a launch. The game was buggy, with spells like Freezing Touch and Burning Hands not working, and all sorts of great stuff.

I originally wrote off the acrobatics system as faulty, however it didn't tell me that you needed certain ranks in the Acrobatics skill to use certain dodge rolls and flips. This was pretty nice, albeit unexplained. Perhaps the Freezing Touch and Burning Hands problem was a matter of the skill system too? I don't know.

The matter at hand here is that the game was rereleased in 2012 in the form you see now. It was entirely reworked: An engine overhaul, new systems, fancy effects, a point-and-click mode, etc.

The original version of the game always had co-op, through LAN or internet play. Now, we have Steam for eight-player co-op.

I'm going to highlight some of the main differences between the versions here:

The spell system: In the original, you could usually find spells out in the wilderness as loot, and depending on your starting class you may have started with one or two. As far as I know you may have been able to put ranks in any type of magic skill and use it, but I may be wrong. In this Steam Edition, you get one spell per level, and each class seems to have a certain type of magic they use, that they learn each level.

The skill system: In the original, there were many types of skills, and you could rank up in any one you pleased using a skill point. In this version of the game, your skills gain experience in a similar way to how you level up in The Elder Scrolls or Final Fantasy II: You use something, it gains experience. You gain skill points every level, but if you use one on a skill, it just gives it an experience boost, and will not guarantee a level up. I'm personally not much a fan of this.

The graphics: The game now has fancy bloom and fog, and WORKING particle effects! The UI is a little less polished than it originally was, but I still find it enjoyable.

The multiplayer: Hoo boy, is this game a hoot to play online. The bugs or simple obscurity of practically EVERYTHING in this game makes this game a laugh to play with others. The Collector's Edition is absolutely riddled with bugs or quirks, while the netcode works well. Saves are confusing, but the bugs and problems make the game hilarious! I have yet to test the game in this Steam Edition, but various skills now apply to your allies as well as yourself. It creates a new dynamic that wasn't present in the original.

The verdict: Not mentioned above: The physics of this version aren't as... Tight, so to say, as the original/Collector's Edition, and the old spell system was quite nice. This version's difficulty seems much easier than the original's, and in the first dungeon alone I leveled up five times more than I usually did in the original! This isn't so much a problem, but it's interesting to say the least.

If you want a solid RPG and don't mind the price tag, get this version! If you want a laugh and a more solid system (WHEN it works) then play the original or the Collector's Edition. Either way, it's an RPG on the PC with cooperative multiplayer. A+ From me!

reviewText:
'Dungeon Lords Steam Edition' - maybe another way to call it would be:
'Okay boys, Dungeon Lords Take #4: Let's try not to screw it up this time. Lights, camera, action!'
___________________________________________________________________________________

'Tl;dr'
First the good part': This time it seems the developers care for the game as they released their first patch after the release. This one adressed several problems in MP - unfortunately the SP seems mostly untouched. So now it's important to see if they release more patches to fix bugs and glitches or if it was a one-time wonder.

'Fans' of the old Dungeon Lords:

This version is better than 'MMXII' but if there was a bug or glitch in the original version it's quite possible that it is still there and wasn't fixed. However the game is more accessible (there are e.g. finally tool tips for skills and spells), a quest log gives you some hints where to go and the randomized loot is quite interesting - so there are several positive changes. However maybe it would be better to wait some more weeks and see if the developers now actually care for their game and support SP and MP it or if it will be abandonned once more.

'Newcomers' who have never heard of or played the original game:

It's probably better to skip this game, there are better RPGs out there. It has its own charm (quite trashy and retro) but to find the positive things you have to dig deep in a game full of bulky and weird systems and design decisions.
___________________________________________________________________________________

Oh Lord, that game is like an undead, It was a bit rotten the first time it was released in 2005 (and full of bugs), afterwards it came back in an 'improved' version (still a buggy mess) and some years after it returned from its grave with the 'MMXII' version (did I mention the bugs?) that had 'improved systems' (official claim) and some nice function additions - however at the same time they also screwed up the once good leveling and magic system and removed interesting features like identification, the whole exploring aspect or the penalty systems. I regretted buying this game quite fast.

Well so now here's the Steam Edition that is based on an improved 'MMXII' version and should finally act as a 'complete and finished' version. So do all good things come in... fours?

First there is to say that the original game was neither very good nor very polished but it had its own charm. 'Dungeon Lords' provided some very interesting concepts (e.g. the nice character and class system that I still remember in very good ways), challenging dungeons with good puzzles, interesting secrets (like the 'Demon Key' from 'Naga Temple') and had a great 'retro' feel. It wasn't very special but back then it entertained me quite good despite the many flaws.
Seriously there was a ton of bugs, terrible game design decisions and glitches: awful animations, missing loading screens, absolutely empty cities and buildings, nearly everything was unfunctional, figuring out stuff was made in hell (tutorial or explanations of the items/spells/skills... what's that?) and it felt like a bulky mess overall.
However I enjoyed it for quite some time back then and I still remember my badass Ninjutsu-Nethermagic character (Rogue + Mage class combination) in a good way.

Unfortunately they changed the game a lot back in the 'MMXII' version: they e.g. swaped the skill system for a cookie-cutter version, the new magic system was 'boring' and much stuff was still not working as intended. Anyway the worst thing was that they abandoned the 'new' game very fast and didn't care for updates or fixes for the problems.
Together with some others I voluntereed as tester and translator for the german version and spent many hours with translating the tool tips and looking for glitches and bugs (trust me, that list was long) but in the end it didn't even matter (many hours were wasted back then).

So now there's this 'new' version and I've been looking at it with a lot of critical thoughts in mind. However I thought 'Can't be worse than the last version' and started another 'adventure'. That was some hours ago...

... and I can say it's better. Way better than the MMXII version and in most parts better than the original version. I didn't encounter any huge bugs or crashes (the small ones they belong to the game like heat to fire), they finally added necessary options and higher difficulties, changing your weapon manually is possible once again and the map's hidden again.
Besides there is also the good stuff from 'MMXII' like the way better interface, hotkeys for spells and items, randomized loot and tool tips. They improved the weird systems to make them kind of okay (I'd still kill for the old character and class system) and overall it's running quite smoothly (in comparison to the 'whole time stuttering' and the awful loading times of the earlier versions'...).
________________________________________________________________________________

So... can I recommend the game? Well that's a difficult question.

The 'Steam Edition' version is definitely 'okay' and way better than the last one but it's necessary to see what the developers will do with all the feedback and the information they are now able to get from the players. Will they fix stuff (e.g. the problem with the lines/voice of NPCs: if you click at a person several times he will repeat his whole dialogue that many times. That's absolutely awful ingame) or abandon the game like the last version? They released one patch that adressed the MP but I would prefer improvements to the SP.

In addition it's 'Dungeon Lords' - that game was a special kind of trashy RPG and will stay that way no matter what you'll do. The animations are awful, the world's empty, the story has more clichés than an 80's movie, the technical aspects are totally outdated, it feels horrible in so many ways...
... but damned, I still kind of like it. It's such a special game. In a way somebody would say 'Oh he's such a special boy'. I'd rate it a 6 out of 10 (maybe only because the original version was one of the first RPGs I've ever played and there are some good memories besides bugs and glitches...)

I trend towards a recommendation, but mostly for players of the original 'Dungeon Lords' who didn't already hate it back then. However the recommendation depends totally on the question if the developers are willing to continue the support for the game. Else it will fail the same way as its 'parents'. There's much stuff to fix but deep down there's potential for a nice entertaining oldschool RPG. Maybe you should wait grabbing it until the developers show that they now care for their game and support it with fixes and patches...

And for most of the others ones, who have never played or even heard of 'Dungeon Lords'  (probably 85%): Skip it, there's better stuff out there. Way better stuff. There are too many bad design decisions and bulky systems to bother with until you may see some positive aspects. However the RPG has definitely potential for some hilarious and funny times - and if it only be due to bugs, glitches or weird things happening and you raging about everything.

reviewText:
I should start this by saying that I have probably played over 200 hours of this game before it came to Steam.

If you give this game a chance, it will surprise you.

It looks a little dated and its gameplay is a little clunky - but beneath that there is a charming, difficult, frustrating, and rewarding Action RPG.

Give it a shot. There's a lot in this game to be discovered.

reviewText:
Played the original when it came out and am delighted it's rereleased.
Game reminds me of my beloved wife.
A little old, somewhat quirky and lacks polish.
However...
It knows how to have fun. It scratches that ARPG itch.
Only game I've ever seen that lets you play as a lefty (otherwise, there is no satisfaction).
Elemental spells let you feel like a magical wrecking ball, setting people on fire and watching them stagger about.
Rogue stealth is satisfying, picking locks is challenging, being a fighter is.. dunno.. never willingly played a meat-shield in any game (might even try being a priest in thie next run).
Haven't had this much fun since Dragon Age: Origins.
It's sad that this buggy mess still manages to be more entertaining than most of Fallout 4 (to me).
Pretty good value for less than $20.00.

reviewText:
Introduction
Dungeon Lords, a (4th version) fantasy ARPG by D.W. Bradly. Who the hell is that? It is a guy who made pathbreaking RPGs like Wizardry 6 and 7.....about 24 years ago. Hey I was also pretty skilled in athletics during the 80s. Nevermind.


The game itself in short terms:

Singleplayer:
- if you played dungeon lords before and liked it, give it a go (there are still many minor bugs though)
- otherwise....well check the demo from the old version first

Multiplayer:
- would be fun, BUT ongoing connectivity losts -> BROKEN


Conclusion
Hopefully the game will be fully patched or receive mod support. But there is no guarantee or roadmap.
For old school nerds positive +, for newcomer and multiplayer (maybe) negative - .
But nerding always wins, so it is recommended.

reviewText:
On the whole, I did enjoy it.  The graphics have been updated somewhat so they don't look horrible, and the inventory system has been overhauled somewhat to make it clear how much stuff you can haul around before needing to get rid of something.

Unfortunately, trying to sell multiples of something to a vendor means needing to close the inventory screen to select how much you're selling, then reopening it to sell the next item.  Also, the change to the class/skills means that alot of the freedom of the original game has been lost, as you are no longer free to spend your experience to increase your skills and attributes as you wish, instead having a much more limited pool of attribute and skill points gained each level.  And, you no longer have 2 Basic, 2 Advanced, and 1 Master class, but 2 Basic, 1 Advanced, and 1 Master, decreasing your options even more.

Still, it's a decent enough RPG, especially if you can pick it up during a sale.

reviewText:
So this is pretty much the gist of it: I play coop with friend. I crash, randomly and almost normally now. Every time I do, he says that the previous savegames get destroyed, leaving only the last one and without my own character in them.

This not only means that I lose all progress in the different questlines but also that quest items DO NOT TRANSFER OVER as they are supposed to. We were doing the Shadow Ruins with my pal and I happened to grab the shadowslayer sword. After I crashed, then the sword was nowhere to be found and any previous saves to the CTD got DELETED without a trace.

End result, 15 hours of gameplay down the drain since now we can't finish the game.

This MUST get fixed soon. We can put up with CTDs, bugs, faulty mechanics and what not, but the game cannot be played to completion in it's current state.

If you charged for this remastered" software at least have the decency to FIX some of the problems that have plagued it for more than a decade! I used to play the original one and it still has the same bugs.

So
recommended: fix this.\n\nThumbs down for now and because for some reason I couldn't create a topic on the discussions tab."

reviewText:
My friend bought this for me on sale to play the co-op features with him. He got a copy as well.

We played 119 minutes of it in one sitting. Right out of the gate, it was quirky and CLEARLY dated, but we loved it. The combat mechanics were so bad, and there was no real sense of story or purpose. We were just slaughtering things because some guy told us to go do it. For unspecified reasons. We were laughing the entire time.

We saved the game and quit out for the day, thoroughly convinced that it was a good purchase just because of how much fun we had.

Today, we attempted to play again. We got into a lobby together, loaded our save, and anytime I hit 'Start Game', it would load to 100% on my end and then freeze. Meanwhile, on my friend's end, it just stayed on the lobby screen.

This is the best game I've ever played. I cannot stop laughing.

reviewText:
Don't worry about my time played, I have spent hundreds of hours playing this game.

It may look a little shabby at first, but if you have the heart to jump into it and delve into the story and the gameplay you will be pleasantly surprised.

It's not perfect but it is the RPG that I've come to know and love over the years and has earned the title of my favorite game of all time.

My username and picture is from my character in the game, that's how memorable it is.

reviewText:
11/10

pros:
+ good gameplay
+ interesting world (speaking the diverse dungeons and puzzles)
+ the randomized loot

cons:
- buggy piece of ♥♥♥♥ in multiplayer, but i managed to play it via direct IP without too much lagg
- kinda empty world (very few sidequests, random npcs with actual dialogue)

The main issue of Multiplayer:
- questline can be easily bugged by ppl looting quest items. you then have to save, make the character with the quest items leave so they get back to the host. Save again and reload the other players into the game.
- the lagg can be silly, simply unplayable.

Dungeon Lords Steam Edition is one of many tries to release a proper playable version of it. And against all odds I have to say they finally did it. You can play the game without any gamebreaking hickups if you dont bug yourself across borders you shouldnt be able to pass yet or to jump behind doors you activated and can only be activated by that lever and be stuck behind it.

The gameplay is fun even doe the challenge isnt really there, once you hit the highest levels every mob is laughably easy and if you have randomized loot that rolled a tad too high (yes iam looking at you pants with 500 armor) they dont even deal damage to you at all anymore. Except all the little flaws, like ranged combat being way to weak to have proper uses other than cheesing way to hard enemys early on, or Cataclysm oneshotting pretty much any mob, yes even bosses, the game has suprisingly interesting characters and riddles.

Summing it all up Dungeon Lords Steam Edition is an interesting RPG but cant hold up with modern titles in terms of production quality and immersion. I still can recommend it to RPG fans who like action combat and to ppl whose pcs are too weak for the fancy tripple A titles of today.

reviewText:
This review is mainly for people who played the original game back in 200X.

I played this game back in the day when it was chock full of bugs, empty towns, characters that were void of any interest and a multiplayer system that would cause the game to crash...

And you know what? I loved it.

For some reason there was a charm to the way that the game allowed you to stand there, shooting your bow for 20+ minutes to kill enemies that were never meant to be fought at your level, finally killing them and gaining hundreds of thousands of experience points. The game also rewarded you for playing on harder difficulties by rewarding more experience.

I remember doing backflips in full plate armour over mountains to reach areas that were meant for the final hours of the game. The way I was able to increase my speed so my jump attacks would shred the enemies like a wood chipper was also hilarious.

The game's mechanics made it fun, giving you the ability to use whatever spells you find as long as you had the proper ingredients, equip whatever weapons and armour you wanted with penalties if you didn't have the required stats and of course the magical power to pause the game in any menu and wait for your stuns and debuffs to wear off while the myriad of enemies politely wait for you to check your stats or find that spellbook that you really need.

If I were to give it an honest rating, it'd likely be a 3/10. It wasn't a good game at all, though it was fun and hilarious despite all these shortcomings. I would compare it to movies like The Room" or "Spiderman 3"

reviewText: If it's on sale for really cheap and you're looking for a game to muck around on for a while, go ahead and pick this game up for a few hours of fun before realizing what a chore the actual game is.\nI'm not even going to go into the bugs. It's obvious what kind of a game this is, read the other reviews. If you jump at doorways prepare to get stuck, if you climb up underneath a platform that's too close prepare to get stuck, if you jump into a small hole prepare to get stuck, etc. (CURSE YOU HALL OF LORDS)\nI think the biggest thing for me was how disappointing this game actually was. I mean there's just so much here that screams I can be good if you let me" but the devs clearly had no idea where to take the game. Much of the game is hidden away so you'll need to be prepared to read information online on which quests to take for which classes/guilds and heraldry but most of the guides are kind of outdated. One I read had stat requirements for the classes which I can only assume was for the classic as this version has no such requirements. The game won't tell you that you will pick a total of 5 classes. Two classes come from the original 4 (Fighter/Adept/Mage/Rogue)

reviewText:
If you have not played the Collectors Edition this might be a fun game for you.  However having played the CE the revamp on Dungeon Lords just absolutely destroyed the best parts of the game.  What made CE great was the simplicity of the training system, the simplicity of the equipment and magic systems.  The ability to use spells on the run etc...  The revamp has made all this unwieldy and for lack of a better term a clusterfrick.  The training system sucks.  This new system for damaged weapons and armor sucks.  You can't kill a group of wolves without having to repair your sword or axe.  How is it supposed to be fun when you do nothing but repair every time you have to kill a bat or rat...

The old version definitely had it's quircks and draw backs.  But they tried to revamp to much with the new release.

The Negatives:  New magic system, constant equipmant repairs, new item storage system, combat system (who decided to make you run when you move to the left instead of side stepping?) new training system sucks.

The Positives:  It appears some of the old crash bugs are fixed.  Graphics are better.  Fewer compatibility issues with new OS and screen resolutions.

reviewText: I need to update this review. I had been messing around with the windows Icons for a while. Some games have problems with Win 7 and Win 10 due to the fact that the Operating Systems has changed the way the Mouse Device Context works and sometimes you have to reduce the game into windows mode to get the mouse cursor to work with the mouse. That happened with the game Titan Quest." But
date: I could not find such feature on the Dungeon Lords icon on the startup bar. So I went directly to the DL Steam Edition application exe. file and right clicked and brought up the properties panel. Went to the Compatability tab and changed the compatability mode for Win XP Service Pack 3 and checked the boxes for Disable display scaling on high DPI settings and Run as Administrator. That fixed the problems. So far

reviewText:
I remember buying the Collector's Edition when it came out and loved it and when I saw that it was finally coming to Steam, I instantly bought it thinking that it'll be more refined and will work better with today's operating systems, and I am personally using Windows 7, which may or may not have anything to do with the game crashing constantly after a certain point in the story.

In the game, Emmindor tells you to take Galdryn's Horn to Talendor.  I did just that and went back to talk to him again about what next to do in the story.  After a couple of sidequests, I go back to Fargrove and the guards started attacking me as expected, but I did what I did when I had the CE.  I ran past them and tried to get into Fargrove.  Upon pressing E on the door into Fargrove, the game stopped and went black with text in a red outlined box describing an error.  I decided to close the game and end the process manually, but when opening the game again and clicking Load, the game stops working completely.  I figured it may be the extensive amount of saved games that I had, so I deleted a lot of them and the game would still crash.  I started a new character to see if I could load that game after exiting, and the game would still continue crashing.

I still plan on playing around with how to get it to start working again, but for now this excuse of a great game gets a negative review until this is fixed or I find a fix, which I will include in an edited review.    It's disappointing to me that I get a really good character going (Thrall, rogue/fighter/knight/hunter) compared to the one I had in the CE, only to see that I can't load a game without it crashing upon clicking Load Game.

reviewText:
When Dungeon Lords first came out in 2005 I was eagerly awaiting this game because i was and still am a huge fan of David W. Bradleys RPGs: Having Finished Wizardry 6+7 and Wizards&Warriors I hope for another milestone in RPG-Gaming.

But having instantly bought it I was really dissappointed: The game was very bugged and unfinished. Now after all those years - i skipped the collectors Edition as well as the reissue as DLMMXII - I bought the steam version and finally could recognize the game in a state it should always have been: It IS a truly great RPG and the design of David W. Bradley is really visibile. During my playtrough I just encountered one bought: The Auto-Save-Function is not working properly because the autosaved games are not loadable (DL always crashes). But this was not a problem.

In short: I enjoyed playing and finishing the game a lot: Highly recommended for Retro-Computer-RPG-Fans.

reviewText: Yes there may be bugs, and yes it may crash randomly at times, but overall this is still a worthwhile game to play, still fun even with some of the quirkiness.  In my case the biggest concern I have is that there were some interesting features of earlier versions of the game excluded, such as the ability to have a shield equipped with a polearm.  There are NPCs that are still able to do so however, one example being Ruenkava the Valkyrie, wielding that nasty winged destroyer in one hand while also having a Fathien War Shield equipped.  Unfortunate that I want to play the Valkyrie class but have to choose between a two-handed polearm, or a Sword and Shield since I got a really nice shield I'd like to use.
